problem:
The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees.
solution:
First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.

We have that
\begin{align*}
&\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\
&= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
&= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ.
\end{align*}The terms of the sum
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
\begin{align*}
\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\
&= 2 \cos n^\circ,
\end{align*}which is real.  Therefore,
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.  Let
\[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
model_solution:
## Step 1: Identify the terms in the given sum as complex numbers in trigonometric form.
The given sum consists of terms in the form $\text{cis } \theta$, where $\text{cis } \theta = \cos \theta + i \sin \theta$. This represents complex numbers on the unit circle in the complex plane.

## Step 2: Recognize that the sum can be viewed as a sum of vectors in the complex plane.
Each term $\text{cis } \theta$ can be thought of as a vector from the origin to a point on the unit circle. The sum of these vectors will result in a new vector that can also be represented in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$.

## Step 3: Notice the symmetry and the progression of angles in the given sum.
The angles are in an arithmetic progression from $75^\circ$ to $147^\circ$ with a common difference of $8^\circ$. The average of the first and last term is $(75^\circ + 147^\circ) / 2 = 111^\circ$.

## Step 4: Apply the concept that the argument of the sum of complex numbers in trigon
## Step 5: Determine the argument of the sum using the average angle.
Since the angles are evenly distributed and the sum can be viewed as a vector sum, the argument of the sum will be the same as the average angle of the first and last terms. Thus, the argument $\theta$ of the sum is $111^\circ$.


The final answer is: $\boxed{111}$

## Step 1: Identify the terms in the given sum as complex numbers in trigonometric form.
The given sum consists of terms in the form $\text{cis } \theta$, where $\text{cis } \theta = \cos \theta + i \sin \theta$. This represents complex numbers on the unit circle in the complex plane.

## Step 2: Recognize that the sum can be viewed as a sum of vectors in the complex plane.
Each term $\text{cis } \theta$ can be thought of as a vector from the origin to a point on the unit circle. The sum of these vectors will result in a new vector that can also be represented in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$.

## Step 3: Notice the symmetry and the progression of angles in the given sum.
The angles are in an arithmetic progression from $75^\circ$ to $147^\circ$ with a common difference of $8^\circ$. The average of the first and last term is $(75^\circ + 147^\circ) / 2 = 111^\circ$.

## Step 4: Apply the concept that the argument of the sum of complex numbers in trigon

## Step 5: Determine the argument of the sum using the average angle.
Since the angles are evenly distributed and the sum can be viewed as a vector sum, the argument of the sum will be the same as the average angle of the first and last terms. Thus, the argument $\theta$ of the sum is $111^\circ$.


The final answer is: $\boxed{111}$
